title-group.article-title: Law, Religion, and the Metaphysics of Abortion: A Reply to Simmons

contrib.role: associate professor of philosophy, culture and law

aff.institution: Trinity Graduate School, Trinity International University

fn.p: B.A., University of Nevada, Las Vegas; M.A., Simon Greenleaf University; M.A., Ph.D., Fordham University; M.J.S. candidate, Washington University School of Law, St. Louis

where he holds adjunct appointments in both Trinity Law School and Trinity Evangelical Divinity School. He is author of Abortion and the Sanctity of Human Life, The Abortion Controversy 25 Years After Roe v. Wade: A Reader, 2nd ed., Affirmative Action: Social Justice or Reverse Discrimination?, Politically Correct Death: Answering the Arguments for Abortion Rights, and The Mormon Concept of God: A Philosophical Analysis. He and Dennis Hollinger are the general editors of the Eerdman's Critical Issues in Bioethics monograph series. He is author of more than fifty articles in numerous journals such as Journal of Law, Medicine, and Ethics, Social Theory and Practice, Journal of Social Philosophy, International Philosophical Quarterly, Public Affairs Quarterly, Nexus, A Journal of Opinion, and Logos: Philosophic Issues in Christian Perspective. Special interests include applied ethics, legal and political philosophy, and philosophy of religion. Special thanks to Trinity International University's Board of Regents for providing me a sabbatical and leave of absence in order to work on this essay as well as other research in law and religion. If not for the support of Winston Frost, Dean, Trinity International University, I would not have been the recipient of the board's graciousness.
